questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for elasticity in skeletal muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Titin

Titin is responsible for muscle elasticity. Titin binds the Z- line to the M-line. The titin molecules act as a framework that holds the myosin and actin filaments in place so that the contractile machinery of the sarcomere will work.

choices.text: Fast muscle fibres are recruited before slow muscle fibres
Large muscle fibres are recruited before small muscle fibres
Well perfused muscle fibres are recruited before poorly perfused muscle fibres
Strong muscle fibres are recruited before weak muscle fibres

questions.text: During a graded activity which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Well perfused muscle fibres are recruited before poorly perfused muscle fibres

As per the size principle, type 1 muscle fibres are recruited before type 2 muscle fibres. Type 1 muscle fibres are slow, small diameter fibres, with oxidative metabolism. They are red in appearance, well perfused with high capillary density, more mitochondria and more myoglobin as compared to the type 2 fibres. Type 2 fibres are fast, large diameter fibres, with glycolytic metabolism. These are white in appearance.

choices.text: Increases urine output, efferent arteriole dilation
Increases urine output, afferent arteriole dilation
Increases urine output, efferent arteriole constriction
Decreases urine output, afferent arteriole dilation

questions.text: A researcher observes that caffeine affects urine output through an effect on GFR. What is the effect and mechanism involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Caffeine’s primary effect is to increase urine output via afferent arteriole dilation. It causes relaxation of vascular smooth muscle of afferent arteriole, thus increases RPF and hence hydrostatic pressure in glomerular capillaries.

questions.text: Resting length corresponds with which of the following sarcomere lengths?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

2 µ

During an isometric contraction, maximum strength of contraction and maximum tension occurs when the initial length of sarcomere is 2.0 to 2.2 µ. This initial length a which tension generated is maximum is k/a optimum length or resting length.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is admitted to CCU with acute myocardial infarction. A few days later his 24-hr urinary output was decreased. An increase in which of the following contributes to this reduced urine flow in a patient with congestive heart failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

In a patient with heart failure, reduced urine flow is due to increased renal sympathetic activity. ANP & Urodilantin (32 aa synthesised in renal tubular cells) both increase sodium and water excretion in urine.

choices.text: Free water clearance is negative when urine is hypotonic
Free water clearance is negative when urine is hypertonic
Free water clearance is positive when urine is isotonic
Free water clearance is same as urine flow rate

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about free water clearance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Free water clearance is negative when urine is hypertonic or concentrated

questions.text: A patient has a urine concentration of a substance of 20mg/mL, urine flow rate of 5mL/min and plasma concentration of 10 mg/mL. What is the clearance of this substance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

10 mL/min, U X V / P = 20 X 5 / 10 = 10 mL/min.

choices.text: Stimulation of aldosterone release from zona glomerulosa
Decreased sodium reabsorption in renal tubules

questions.text: All except the following are effect of Ang-II-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ang- II directly increases sodium reabsorption in PCT & TAL.

questions.text: Calculate RPF when GFR= 125 mL/min and FF= 0.2.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

FF= GFR/ RPF, RPF= GFR/FF= 125/0.2= 625 mL/min.

choices.text: From onset of Q to onset of first heart sound
From onset of Q to onset of second heart sound

From onset of Q to onset of fourth heart sound

questions.text: If ECG, phonocardiogram and carotid pressure changes are being recorded simultaneously, which of the following describes total electromechanical systole?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

If ECG, phonocardiogram and carotid pressure changes are being recorded simultaneously, QS2 or total electromechanical systole is from onset of Q to onset of second heart sound. We can also measure the LVET or left ventricular ejection time, which is from onset of carotid pressure rise to the dicrotic notch.

PEP or pre-ejection period is QS2 – LVET.

questions.text: What is the duration of the nodal delay?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Duration of the nodal delay is 0.09s or 92millisec. The impulse slows down as it passes through the AV node because (i) AV node has small diameter fibres which conduct at a velocity of 0.05m/sec. (ii) AVN has very few or no gap junctions.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about amylin?

A. It is secreted by beta cells of pancreas

B. Ratio of insulin and amylin is 100:1

C. It enhances gastric emptying

D. It is a 37-residue peptide hormone

E. It increases glucagon secretion
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

A, B, D

• Amylin is a 37- residue peptide hormone which is co secreted with Insulin from the beta cells of pancreas in a ratio of 100:1. 

• It inhibits glucagon secretion, delays gastric emptying, and acts as a satiety agent.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:

1-b, 2- f, 3- c, 4- b

C- peptide- beta cells

Ghrelin- epsilon cells

Somatostatin- delta cells

Amylin- beta cells

questions.text: Change in sex hormone binding globulin will most affect levels of which of these hormones?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Testosterone is transported with the help of sex hormone binding globulin. Sex hormone binding globulin binds androgens and estrogen. 

Estrogen increases the level of SHBG. Estrogenic states such as, oral contraceptives, pregnancy, hyperthyroidism, cirrhosis, anorexia, certain drugs are associated with increased SHBG. 

Progesterone, cortisol and other steroids are transported by transcortin. 

DHEA does not require protein for transport.

choices.text: Decreases the activity of H+K+ ATPase
Increases the activity of H+K+ ATPase
Increases the activity of Na+ H+ exchanger

questions.text: What is the effect of aldosterone on acid secretion in the kidney?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Aldosterone increases the activity of H+K+ ATPase in DCT and CD.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is repolarized last during ventricular repolarization?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Repolarization of ventricles occur from epicardium to endocardium.

questions.text: Closure of Ca2+ channels and slow delayed increase of K+ efflux occur in which phase of pacemaker potential-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Late rapid repolarization is Phase 3 of pacemaker potential characterized by closure of Ca2+ channels and slow delayed increase of K+ efflux.

questions.text: All except the following contribute to high conduction velocity in Purkinje fibres-
questions.solution:

Purkinje fibres have low myofibril content so they contract very little or not at all during impulse transmission and hence have high conduction velocity.

IPSP is hyperpolarizing membrane potential that shifts membrane potential far away from firing level.

questions.text: A physiologist is studying blood flow in a network of four parallel blood vessels. The resistance of each vessel is 20 R and the pressure at the proximal end of the vessel is 110 mmHg and pressure at the distal end is 10 mmHg. What is the total blood flow rate through the network of vessels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Total resistance is = 1/20 + 1/20 + 1/20 + 1/20= 1/R  So, R= 20/4= 5 

Blood flow or Q = 110- 10 (Pressure gradient) / R= 5 

Q = 20 L/s

Baroreceptor reflex is most rapidly acting mechanism.

questions.solution:

Digitalis increases the contractility of heart and hence shifts the curve upward and to the left.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male presents with a neurodegenerative condition involving impaired glutamate regulation. Which type of glial cell is primarily involved in glutamate regulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Astrocytes maintain glutamate levels by absorbing excess glutamate preventing excitotoxicity.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with severe muscle stiffness and muscle spasms, including trismus and rigidity, after stepping on a rusty nail 3 weeks ago. Which snare protein is responsible for these symptoms by interfering with neurotransmitter release at the neuromuscular junction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tetanus toxin decreases the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA & Glycine by inhibiting the v SNARE protein Synaptobrevin.

questions.text: Which of the following is essential for calculating the cardiac output using Fick’s principle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Measurement of oxygen uptake by the lungs and arteriovenous oxygen content difference. This method is based on the principle that the total uptake of the substance by an organ is equivalent to the product of blood flow to that organ and arteriovenous difference of the substance.

questions.text: In a person on a high potassium diet, which part of the nephron would be expected to reabsorb the most potassium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

PCT

S2 is just heard before the T wave

questions.text: During a cardiac examination 30-year-old patient’s simultaneous ECG and phonocardiography are recorded.  Which of the following statements most accurately describe the relationship between second heart sound and ECG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

S 2 typically occurs at the end of T wave and subsequent P wave. This timing corresponds to the end of ventricular systole and beginning of ventricular diastole when the semilunar valves close.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with episodes of tingling and numbness in his left arm. A reflex hammer test on patient’s biceps tendon noted a weaker than normal biceps- jerk reflex  and decision to use Jendrassik’s maneuver to enhance the reflex was taken. Which of the following is directly activated by Jendrassik’s maneuver?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The jendrasssik maneuver which can involve actions such as clenching of teeth or pulling on hands activates A gamma motor neurons which innervate intrafusal fibres and hence increasing muscle spindle sensitivity.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with muscle spasms and difficulty with precise movements of hands & fingers. Upon examination, the patient has hyperactive deep tendon reflexes and experiences a persistent tremor during voluntary movements. Which of the following fibres, would most likely cause this hyperactive deep tendon reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Nuclear bag dynamic fibres are highly sensitive to rate of change of stretch. When a muscle is stretched rapidly, these fibres fire strongly leading to robust activation of the stretch reflex.

choices.text: PAG – endorphins in the dorsal horn
Periventricular areas- norepinephrine in raphe magnus nucleus
Peri ventricular areas- enkephalins in raphe magnus nucleus

questions.text: 75-year-old presented to emergency after a road traffic accident with severe pain. The intern on duty administered morphine, knowing its action on supraspinal pain pathway. Which of the following brain regions and neurotransmitters are correctly paired and activated by morphine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

PAG – endorphins in the dorsal horn. Periaqueductal gray & Peri ventricular areas activate the raphe magnus nuclei (serotonin) and Locus ceruleus (NE).

choices.text: The first order neurons terminate in Lamina-II
It primarily carries fast pain sensations
All fibres terminate exclusively in reticular formation

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about neospinothalamic pain pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Neospinothalamic pathway is for fast pain sensations.

questions.text: A patient reports unusual sensitivity to temperature changes and physician suspects a disorder related to thermoreceptors. Which of the following accurately describes the nerve fibres involved in transmitting signals from thermoreceptors?
questions.solution:

Warmth sensation is carried by both A delta & C fibres in pain transmission.

questions.text: A 65-year-old war wounded soldier recently had his left leg amputated below the knee. He complains of pain in the missing limb sometimes triggered by touching his thigh. Which statement best explains the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:

Cortical plasticity- reorganization of brain cortical areas is the reason for the pain.

questions.text: Which of the following is the main contributor to the corticospinal tract in terms of percentage of descending fibres?

Somatosensory areas contribute 40% to total fibres.

questions.text: All except the following statements about amygdala is true-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Amygdala is a part of limbic system central, controlling emotions and motivations. It is connected with the prefrontal cortex and hippocampus for acquisition, consolidation and retrieval of emotional memory. Damage to anterior temporal lobes including the amygdalae (almond shaped nuclei located deep within temporal lobes) result in Kluver Bucy Syndrome – lack of fear, hyperphagia, hypersexuality and hyperorality and excessive curiosity.

At FRC, the elastic recoil of the lungs and the chest wall are balanced.

Maximum intra- alveolar pressure is +1 during mid of expiration

RV= 1200 mL

questions.text: All except the following statements are true regarding the OHDC-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Plateau phase ranges from 60-100 mmHg. This phase maintains high Hb saturation despite moderate PO2 decreases. Steep phase ranges from 10-60 mmHg ensures efficient O2 unloading when small drops in PO2 cause significant O2 release, crucial for hypoxic conditions & active muscles.

Are stimulated to decrease rate and depth of ventilation

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the central chemoreceptors?
questions.solution:

Central chemoreceptors are located below the surface of ventrolateral medulla. Increased H+ ion in CSF is the primary stimulus.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient is admitted to hospital with COPD exacerbation. He appears short of breath and has a low oxygen saturation. ABG analysis reveals- pH of 7.2. PO2 = 50mmHG, PCO2= 70 mmHG, HCO3-= 24 mmoL/L.  What will most likely activate his peripheral chemoreceptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Peripheral chemoreceptors respond to hypoxia ( PaO2< 60> 45mmHG) and acidosis (pH< 7.35).

Saliva is hypotonic and not isotonic secretion.

questions.text: A 30-year-old hiker arrives at the PHS complaining of severe headache, nausea and fatigue since last 12 hours after a rapid ascent to 3000 meters. Physical examination shows signs of mild confusion. What is the most likely reason for the above presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This is a case of acute mountain sickness – in which body’s response to hypoxia is to increase O2 delivery to tissues including brain. The increased CBF leads to elevated hydrostatic pressure in cerebral capillaries leading to edema.

choices.text: Optimum pH for action of Pepsin is 1-2
The final step of protein digestion occurs in the cytosol of enterocytes
Collagen digestion starts in the intestine
Pepsin accounts for 80% of total protein digestion

questions.text: All except the following is false regarding the process of protein digestion-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pepsin initiates digestion of proteins (including the collagen present in meats) in the stomach ( optimum pH is 2-3).

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is found unconscious after a fire in his apartment. Upon investigation, it was discovered that there was a cyanide gas poisoning. The doctor suspects that he is suffering from histotoxic hypoxia. Which of the following is not seen on this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cyanosis is not typically seen in histotoxic hypoxia as the arterial O2 levels and haemoglobin saturation with oxygen remain normal.

choices.text: Loss of voluntary but intact automatic control
Loss of automatic but intact voluntary control
Loss of both automatic and voluntary control

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the Ondine’s curse?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ondine’s curse aka congenital hypoventilation syndrome is a failure of automatic control of breathing leading to hypoxia and hypoventilation, requiring the individual to breathe voluntarily. Most probable site of lesion is Pre- botzinger complex in brainstem.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with fatigue, dyspnoea and sore tongue. Blood tests reveal macrocytic anemia with low vitamin B12 levels. Further testing reveals the presence of anti- intrinsic factor antibodies. What would be seen regarding this patient’s serum gastrin levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pernicious anaemia is an autoimmune condition characterized by autoantibodies against parietal cells. This will lead to decreased HCL levels and thus reduced inhibition of G cells resulting in increased Gastrin levels (often elevated 10-20 times normal).

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with symptoms of steatorrhea and indigestion. Laboratory tests show decreased bicarbonate secretion from the pancreas. Which cells secrete the gastrointestinal hormone most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Secretin is produced by S cells in the duodenum and is responsible for bicarbonate secretion in the pancreas.

MMC occurs at an interval of 60 minutes in the inter-digestive state

questions.text: All except the following statements about MMC is false-

MMC is initiated by motilin and Phase -1 is maximum in duration.

choices.text: Diet lacking in essential fatty acids

questions.text: Shown below are the changes in secretion of T4, T3, RT3 following a dietary modification. Which of the following can produce the changes as seen in the diagram?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

starvation

Normally, T3 > RT3 but in conditions of starvation, any prolonged illness, myocardial infarction, chronic kidney disease, etc., RT3 > T3.

choices.text: Blocked the reuptake of neurotransmitter into pre-synaptic terminals
Bound irreversibly to the receptors on the post-synaptic membrane
Prevented release of acetylcholine from motor neurons

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of nausea and vomiting for about 2 days followed by severe muscle weakness and neurologic symptoms, including ptosis and dysphagia. She gave a history of having eaten at a restaurant the evening before the symptoms began. Laboratory tests were positive for Clostridium botulinum. The basis for the muscle weakness in this case was most likely because the toxin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Prevented release of acetylcholine from motor neurons

Botulinum toxin inactivates the docking proteins in terminals of motor neurons preventing the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junctions.

questions.text: Which of the following type of heat is produced only in a muscle contracting isotonically?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Relaxation heat

Resting heat, initial heat (activation and shortening heat), recovery heat are generated during both in isotonic and isometric muscle contractions. 

If a muscle that has contracted isotonically is restored to its previous length, extra heat in addition to recovery heat is produced and this is k/a relaxation heat. External work must be done on the muscle to return it to its previous length, and relaxation heat is mainly a manifestation of this work.

choices.text: ECF is 20% of total body weight
ICF is 66% of total body weight
CSF is not a transcellular fluid
Total body fluid per unit of body weight is more in females than males

questions.text: Body fluids—plasma, interstitial, and transcellular fluids—moisten tissues, organs, muscles, and skin. Which statement about body fluids is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

ECF is 20% of total body weight

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with mutation of the genes coding for sarcoglycans?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Limb girdle dystrophy

Duchenne’s muscular dystrophy is a serious form of dystrophy in which the dystrophin protein is absent from muscle. It is a X-linked disorder and usually fatal by the age of 30. 

Becker muscular dystrophy is a milder form of the disease where dystrophin is present but reduced in amount. 
Tibialis muscular dystrophy is a genetic muscle disease of titin that destabilizes the folded state of the protein.

questions.text: Which set of changes would be expected to occur in response to direct increases in renal arterial pressure without an intact tubuloglomerular feedback system?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

If there is increase in renal arterial pressure, normally GFR tends to remain unchanged because of mainly the tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism. However, in the absence of TGF, an important renal autoregulatory mechanism, increase in renal arterial pressure will result in a significant increase in GFR, sodium and water excretion.

choices.text: Single Aα motor neuron and all the muscle fibres it supplies
Single muscle fibre and all the Aα motor neurons supplying it
Single sensory neuron and all the muscle fibres it supplies
Single muscle fibre and all the sensory neurons supplying it

questions.text: Which of the following best describes a motor unit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Single muscle fibre and all the Aα motor neurons supplying it

Single A alpha motor neuron and all the muscle fibres it innervates constitute a motor unit. The number of muscle fibres in each motor unit varies. In muscles concerned with fine, graded and precise movements, such as those of the hand and those concerned with movements of the eyeball, each motor unit innervates very few (3- 6) muscle fibres. On the other hand, calf muscles may have up to 600 muscle fibres in each motor unit.

questions.text:
Given below is a graph of the length-tension relationship. Which of the following are true regarding optimum length?

A. Optimum length corresponds to a sarcomere length of 2- 2.2 microns

B. There are maximum number of actin- myosin cross bridges at optimum length

C. There is minimum overlap between actin and myosin

D. Optimum length is also known as the resting length

E. At optimum length, active and passive tension are maximum.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

A, B, D are correct. 

At optimum length, total tension, active tension and passive tension are maximum. Optimum length corresponds to a sarcomere length of 2- 2.2 microns. There is maximum overlap between actin and myosin with maximum number of actin- myosin cross bridges at this length. Optimum length is also known as the resting length.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important controller of coronary blood flow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Although bradykinin, prostaglandins, carbon dioxide and potassium ions are all coronary vasodilators but adenosine is the most important controller of coronary blood flow.

choices.text: Excitatory protein which increases SERCA activity
Inhibitory protein which decreases SERCA activity
Excitatory protein which increases Na+-Ca++ antiport
Inhibitory protein which decreases Na+-Ca++ antiport

questions.text: Phospholamban in cardiac and smooth muscle cells in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Phospholamban is a 6kDa protein that tonically inhibits the SERCA pump by increasing its Km for calcium. It is present in both cardiac and smooth muscle cells.

Phosphorylation of phospholamban relieves this inhibition, speeding up SERCA activity, therefore lowering the cytoplasmic calcium. Phosphorylation of phospholamban is controlled by protein kinases that are, in turn, controlled by agonists. Epinephrine binds to beta receptors on the membrane surface, which are coupled to a heterotrimeric G- protein (Gs) tha activates adenyl cyclase. This increases the intracellular c-AMP which in turn activates protein kinase (PKA).

questions.text: A patient has a GFR of 100mL/min, urine flow rate of 2mL/min and a plasma glucose concentration of 200mg/dL. If the TmG (transport maxima for Glucose) is 250mg/min, what would be this patient’s rate of glucose excretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

0mg/min

Filtered rate of glucose (mg/min) = GFR (mL/min) X plasma glucose (mg/mL)

= 100 X 2

= 200mg/min

The TmG is 250mg/min. Since the filtered rate of glucose is less than the TmG, all of the filtered glucose will be reabsorbed and there is no glucose in urine.

questions.text: Shown below is an electron microscopic picture of a sarcomere. Which of the following represent the H-zone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

A is the dark or A (anisotropic to light) band which consists of myosin and overlapped actin. Within the A-band there is lighter area called the H-zone (D), which consists of only myosin. 

E is the I (isotropic to light) or light band- it consists of only actin.

questions.text:
Given below are the renal clearance curves for different substances


If C is renal clearance of Inulin, curve D corresponds to renal clearance of which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Glucose

Below renal threshold (2mg/mL), clearance of glucose is zero. As the plasma concentration of glucose increases, its clearance also increases and approaches the clearance of inulin but is always less than the clearance of inulin. This is because there will always be some reabsorption of inulin

questions.text: 60% of the total body water in is which of the following compartments?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Intracellular

Two-thirds of the total body water is in the ICF.

questions.text: The equation which is used to calculate the magnitude of the equilibrium potential of a freely diffusible ion is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Donnan and Gibbs showed that in the presence of a non diffusible ion, the diffusible ions distribute themselves so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal. This is the Gibbs Donnan Equation. If a membrane is freely permeable to an ion, magnitude of potential difference for that ion at equilibrium (equilibrium potential or Nernst potential) can be calcuklated by the Nernst Equation.  Goldmann Hodgkin Katz equation is used to calculate the RMP.
Henderson Hasselbach equation is used to calculate the pH of a buffer solution containing given concentrations of an acid and its conjugate base.

questions.text: Gibbs- Donnan equilibrium is based on which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Intracellular proteins

Donnan and Gibbs showed that in the presence of a non-diffusible ion (proteins), the diffusible ions distribute themselves so that equilibrium, their concentration ratios are equal:

This is the Gibbs- Donnan equation. It is applicable for any pair of cations and anions of the same valence.

questions.text: Most of the energy for strenuous exercise that lasts for more than 5- 10 seconds but less than 1 to 2 minutes comes from which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anaerobic glycolysis

ATP stores and ATP from phosphocreatine can sustain exercise for another the first 5- 10 seconds only. Energy for strenuous exercise for more than 5- 10 seconds but less than 1-2 minutes is derived from anaerobic glycolysis. Release of energy by glycolysis occurs much more rapidly than oxidative release of energy, which is much too slow to supply the needs of the muscle in the first few minutes of exercise.

questions.text:
The following events occur at an excitatory synapse. 

A. Ligand- gated channels open in the post synaptic membrane to allow influx of sodium

B. Synaptic vesicles bind to pre-synaptic membrane

C. Depolarization of pre-synaptic membrane

D. Opening of calcium channels cause influx of calcium 

Which of the following is the correct sequence?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

C, D, B, A

Arrival of the action potential at the pre-synaptic membrane, causes opening of calcium channels. This is followed by calcium influx. Vesicles in the pre-synaptic axon terminal bind to the presynaptic membrane. This is followed by exocytosis of the neurotransmitter. The neurotransmitter binds to its receptors on the post synaptic membrane leading to electrical changes in the post- synaptic neuron

questions.text: Most important buffer in the interstitial fluid is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Bicarbonate 

The principal buffer in the interstitial fluid is bicarbonate.

choices.text: ESV first decreases and then increases

questions.text: During exercise in physiological limits what is the effect on end systolic volume?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

During exercise increased sympathetic discharge increases force of contraction of the heart resulting in a better emptying of the ventricles and a decreased end systolic volume.

questions.text: All of the following for tight junctions except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Connexins

Connexins form “gap junctions”.

choices.text: Increased water permeability in the collecting ducts

questions.text: Which of the following will occur in a dehydrated person deprived of water for more than 24 hours?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Increased water permeability in the collecting ducts

In a dehydrated person, increased plasma osmolality and decreased ECF volume will result in increased ADH secretion. ADH increases the insertion of acquporin 2 in the luminal membrane of cells of the collecting duct increasing their permeability to water and therefore, increasing the water reabsorption. Decreased ECF volume increases the plasma renin activity, increases ADH but decreases ANP.

questions.text: All of the following are present on the alpha subunit of the sodium potassium ATPase pump except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Glycosylation site

Glycosylation site is on the beta subunit.

questions.text: Sodium iodide symporter is present in all of the following except
questions.solution:

NIS (secondary active co-transport) is present in

• Thyroid cells

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms for transport across the luminal cell membrane of an enterocyte is present in newborns and infants but not in adults?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Intestinal absorption of immunoglobulins (in colostrum) during early infancy occurs by endocytosis. This ability to absorb large molecules by endocytosis occurs during the first several months of life but is lost thereafter. Simple diffusion, facilitated diffusion, primary and secondary active transports are all normal processes in enterocytes

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

NIS (secondary active co-transport) is present in

• Thyroid cells

Intestinal absorption of immunoglobulins (in colostrum) during early infancy occurs by endocytosis.
