questions.text: Which of the following acquaporins is involved in water reabsorption from the PCT?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Acquaporin 1 is present on both the apical and basolateral membrane of the cells of the PCT. Water reabsorption in the PCT is solute driven and follows the osmotic gradient set up by the active transport of solutes, and isotonicity is maintained.

questions.text:
Membrane potential changes in an isolated cardiac muscle cell are recorded with ion movement across the cell membrane.

Which of the following ion sequences corresponds to regions 1-2-3 on the graph respectively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In a cardiac muscle cell, the depolarization phase is due to influx of sodium. Plateau phase is because of influx of calcium and the repolarization phase is due to efflux of potassium.

questions.text: If an artery is partially occluded by an embolus such that its radius becomes one- half the pre-occlusion value, which of the following parameters will decrease by a factor of 16?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Blood flow is directly proportional to the fourth power of radius. Decrease in radius to half reduces the flow to 1/16th of its pre occlusion value.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to measure the cerebral blood flow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

The Kety- Schmidt method is used to measure the whole brain cerebral blood flow and cerebral metabolic rate  (oxygen extraction and metabolic rate can be measured from arterial and venous samples).

choices.text: Negative feedback system with error of zero
Negative feedback system with correction of zero
Negative feedback system with gain of zero
There is no such thing as infinite gain in a feedback system

questions.text: Which of the following describes infinite feedback gain principle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Negative feedback system with error of zero

For a negative feedback system,

Gain = correction/ error

If error is zero, the gain is infinite.

The control of arterial pressure by the renal- body fluid mechanism, where the arterial pressure always exactly comes back to equilibrium point, makes it an example of infinite feedback gain principle.

choices.text: Safety factor due to low tissue compliance in the negative pressure range is 3 mm Hg
Safety factor due to increased lymph flow is 7 mm Hg
Safety factor due to washout of proteins from the interstitial spaces is 7 mm Hg
Total safety factor of 17 mm Hg implies that the edema results when the capillary hydrostatic pressure is 17 mm Hg

questions.text: All the following are true about the safety factor against edema except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Total safety factor of 17 mm Hg implies that the edema results when the capillary hydrostatic pressure is 17 mm Hg.

Total safety factor against edema is 17 mm Hg. This implies that capillary pressure in a peripheral tissue must theoretically rise by 17 mm Hg before marked edema occurs. The three factors which contribute to safety factor of 17 mm Hg are

(i) Low tissue compliance in the negative pressure range which contributes about 3 mm Hg

(ii) Increased lymph flow which contributes about 7 mm Hg

(iii) Washout of proteins from the interstitial spaces by the increased lymph flow which contributes approximately 7 mm Hg

questions.text: The most important factor which determines the movement of a permeant substance across the cell membrane is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Diffusion coefficient of a substance is determined mainly by the lipid solubility of that substance.

questions.text: In an ideal solution, which of the following is correct? (P is osmotic pressure, n is number of particles, R is gas constant, T is absolute temperature, V is volume)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

P = nRT/V. If T is constant, osmotic pressure is proportional to the number of particles in solution per unit volume of the solution.

questions.text:
The following graph shows the transport kinetics of a solute transferred across cell membrane -

What is the likely nature of the solute:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Since carrier proteins tend to get saturated all carrier mediated transports will have a transport maxima. Glucose is transported by facilitated diffusion which is carrier mediated. Therefore, transport of glucose will show a transport maxima.

questions.text: The blood-cytoplasm gradient generated by pump or leak systems is maximum for which of the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The blood: cytoplasm ratio for Na+ is 12:1, for K+ it is 1:35, for H+ it is 1:2.5, for Ca++ it is 18,000:1.

questions.text: In a clinical study to study the actions of an unknown test solution on RBC volume, 1 mL of heparinized blood is added into 100mL of test solution and mixed. Results show that the RBCs placed into the test solution immediately swell and burst. Into which of the following test solutions were the RBCs placed (intracellular osmolality is 280mosmol/L)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

140mmol of glucose

If the RBCs swell and burst then they must have been added to a hypotonic solution. 140mmol of glucose is equal to 140mosmol of glucose, which is hypotonic.

choices.text: Loss of 1L of blood in a road traffic accident

questions.text:
Given below is a Darrow- Yannet diagram. The normal state (orange and yellow) is superimposed on the abnormal state (dashed lines) to illustrate the shifts in volume (width of rectangle) and total osmolality (height of rectangles) of the extracellular and intracellular fluid compartments.

Which of the following represents the changes (after osmotic equilibrium)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Loss of 1L of blood in a road traffic accident

Loss of 1L of blood is equivalent to loss of iso-osmotic fluid. It will produce a decrease in ECF volume with no change in osmolality.

questions.text: Cholera toxin acts by disrupting which of the following in the intestinal epithelial cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

zonula occludens

Vibrio cholerae releases cholera toxin (CT) and zona occludens toxin (ZOT). CT binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors on the apical surface. The massive secretion of salt and water in cholera-induced diarrhoea involves binding of cholera toxin (CT) to ganglioside GM1 in the apical membrane of intestinal epithelial cells, translocation of the enzymatically active A1-peptide across the membrane, and subsequent activation of adenylate cyclase located on the cytoplasmic surface of the basolateral membrane.

questions.text:
Using the following data, calculate the filtration coefficient for the capillary bed.

Plasma colloid osmotic pressure = 30 mm Hg

Capillary hydrostatic pressure = 40 mm Hg

Interstitial colloid osmotic pressure = 5 mm Hg

Interstitial hydrostatic pressure = 5 mm Hg

Rate of tissue fluid formation = 150mL/min
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

15mL/ min/ mm Hg

Rate of tissue fluid formation = Filtration coefficient X (Pc – πc – Pi + πi)

150mL/ min = Filtration coefficient X (40 – 30 – 5 + 5)mm Hg

Filtration coefficient = 150/10 = 15mL/ min/ mm Hg

questions.text: Which of the following nerve fibres is the least susceptible to local anesthetics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

A gamma nerve fibres are the most susceptible to local anesthetics and C are the least susceptible.

questions.text: Increase in which of the following ion in the ECF has the maximum effect on neuronal excitability?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Explanation- with increase in K+ concentration in ECF, the gradient for potassium will decrease. This causes less K+ to diffuse out from the cell. Increase in positive charge inside the cells causes the membrane potential to become less negative resulting in depolarization and increase in excitability. One of the common symptoms of hyperkalemia is arrythmias.

questions.text: The equilibrium potential for potassium is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

The equilibrium potential or Nernst potential for potassium is -90mV.

questions.text:
The RMP of a cell is -70mV. The equilibrium potentials for important ions under normal physiologic conditions are as follows:-

ECa = +125mV

ENa = +60mv

EMg = 0mV

ECl = -70mV

EK = -90mV

If physiologic conditions are maintained which of the following is likely to flow out of the cells after opening their respective ion channels.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Potassium

Potassium is higher intracellularly. If potassium channels open and the membrane permeability for potassium increases, potassium will move out of the cell till the cell reaches the equilibrium potential of potassium.

choices.text: About 70% of the effect of PaO2 is mediated by the peripheral chemoreceptors
Central effects are mediated by direct effects on cells of the DRG/VRG complex
Sensitivity of the control system is inversely related to the prevailing PaO2
This mechanism is less sensitive than control in response to oxygen

questions.text: With regard to the control of minute ventilation by carbon dioxide
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sensitivity of the control system is inversely related to the prevailing PaO2

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

• The control of ventilation by PaCO2 works primarily through the central chemoreceptors.

• However, the central effects are mediated indirectly through a change in CSF [H+], and the sensitivity is inversely related to PaO2.

questions.text:
Given below are four statements regarding airway resistance of which one or more may be correct. Choose the correct option using the following key.

1. Airway resistance is low in large as well as in small diameter airways

2. Airway resistance is highest in medium sized airways

3. Medium sized airways have a turbulent airflow which increases the resistance to airflow

4. Density of the gas can also affect airway resistance
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ref– Read the text below

Sol:

Airway resistance is low in large as well as in small diameter airways but highest in medium sized airways. Medium sized airways have a turbulent airflow which increases the resistance to airflow. Density of the gas can also affect airway resistance.

questions.text: A person’s normal tidal volume is 400mL with a dead space of 100mL. his respiratory rate is 12 per minute. The person undergoes ventilation during surgery, and the tidal volume is 700mL with a rate of 12 per minute. What is the approximate alveolar Pco2 for this person?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

20 mm Hg. 

Normal alveolar Pco2 is 40 mm Hg. Normal alveolar ventilation is 3.6L/minute. On the ventilator the alveolar ventilation is 7.2L/minute. A doubling of the alveolar ventilation will cause the Pco2 to decrease to half. Thus, the alveolar Pco2 would be 20 mm Hg

questions.text:
Given below are four statements regarding the blood-brain barrier of which one or more may be correct. Choose the correct answer using the following key: - 

1. Blood-brain barrier is formed by the tight junctions between the ependymal cells forming the ventricular walls

2. Blood-brain barrier is formed by the tight junctions between adjacent endothelial cells of the choroid plexus

3. Blood-brain barrier is formed by the tight junctions between adjacent cells of the choroid plexus

4. Astrocytes induce the formation of tight junctions between the endothelial cells
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

Tight junctions between adjacent endothelial of cerebral capillaries form the blood- brain barrier. 

Tight junctions between adjacent choroid epithelial cells represents the structural basis of the blood-CSF barrier. 

Astrocytes induce the formation of tight junctions between the endothelial cells of cerebral capillaries.

questions.text: In an animal experiment the levels of various endogenous compounds are measured in the spinal fluid after application of painful stimuli. One of the compounds that increases because of this experiment is a pentapeptide with a high affinity for delta and mu-receptors. Which of the following substance is most likely to have a common molecular origin with the pentapeptide described above?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ACTH

ACTH is synthesized as a large precursor molecule- POMC or pro opio melanocortin, which id cleaved to form a family of hormones. POMC is hydrolysed to 

• ACTH

• β-lipotropin

• β-endorphin

β-endorphin is an opiod peptide that has five amino acid residues (pentapeptide) of met-enkephalin at its amino terminal end.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a routine check-up. He was on OHAs for the last 12 years but was recently switched to a long-acting insulin due to inadequate blood sugar control. His last serum creatinine was 2.1 mg/dL. The patient’s son, who is a dental student, is concerned about his father’s elevated creatinine level and how it relates his kidney function. Which of the following graphs accurately represents the relationship between GFR and serum creatinine levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

• Creatinine is a substance which is freely filtered and slightly secreted in the PCT. 

• Till the kidney function is almost half of normal there is hardly any change in serum creatinine levels. But as the GFR goes below 60mL/min, there is a steady increase in serum creatinine level. 

• Serum creatinine by itself is not a sensitive indicator of kidney function. 

• Clearance of creatinine is used for the estimation of GFR, though it is not the most accurate. More accurate for GFR estimation is clearance of Inulin.

questions.text: The CNS toxic effects of acute oxygen toxicity in deep sea divers is k/a which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

CNS toxicity, as described originally by Bert, therefore, k/a “Bert effect”, occurred at oxygen pressures of > 3 ATA. However, lower pressures may result in similar effects if exposure is prolonged. 

Symptoms and signs are quite variable but include twitching of perioral and small muscles of the hand, facial pallor, ‘cogwheel’ breathing, thought to be the result of intense peripheral vasoconstriction due to hyperoxia and diaphragmatic twitching respectively 

If exposure is continued, vertigo and nausea, followed by altered behaviour, clumsiness, and finally convulsions result. The convulsions begin with a loss of conciousness and develop in three phases; a tonic phase with a generalized hypertonus lasting for about 1 min, a clonic phase with convulsion for about 2–3 mins and a post critical phase of about 10 mins. The patient has no memory of the crisis. CNS toxicity is hastened by factors such as raised PCO2, stress, fatigue and cold.

Pulmonary symptoms of oxygen toxicity is also k/a Lorain Smith effect. Oxygen at 2 ATA produces characteristic pulmonary signs and symptoms beginning with mild carinal irritation on deep inspiration 3–6 hours into the exposure, intense carinal irritation an uncontrolled cough after about 10 hours and finally chest pain and dyspnoea. Clinical features can be divided into three phases (a) Tracheobronchitis (b) ARDS (c) Pulmonary interstitial fibrosis. Absorption atelectasis due to washout of N2 can lead to collapse of parts of the lung in the event of air trapping.

choices.text: Stimulation of parasympathetic nerves to airways
Release of histamine by mast cells

questions.text: Which of the following is expected to increase the measured airway resistance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

All of the above

Stimulation of parasympathetic nerves causes bronchoconstriction. With low lung volume there is a collapse of the airways, leading to a decreased diameter and increased resistance. Histamine is a bronchoconstrictor.

questions.text: Which point in the figure given below corresponds with arterial blood in a severely anemic patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Point D

In a severely anemic patient there is a decrease in the O2 content of the blood. The O2 saturation of Hb in the arterial blood and the PO2 are not affected.

questions.text: The figure given below shows three different compliance curves- S, T, U for isolated lungs subjected to various transpulmonary pressures. Which of the following best describes the relative compliance for the three lungs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

S > T > U

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit changer in transpulmonary pressure. More the slope, more is the compliance. Compliance of lung S is more than that of T which is more than U.

questions.text: The double Bohr’s effect is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Placental circulation

The “double bohr’s effect” helps to increase fetal oxygenation. The transfer of carbon dioxide from the fetal to the maternal blood shifts the maternal OHDC to the right and fetal curve to the left, facilitating the transfer of oxygen across the placenta from mother to the fetus.

questions.text: Waterfall effect is seen in which of the following zones of the lung?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

zone 2

Zone 2 is the zone of intermittent or pulsatile flow. Waterfall effect is seen in zone 2.

questions.text: The receptors responsible for rapid, shallow breathing are
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

J receptors

J or juxtacapillary receptors located at the alveolo capillary junction are stimulated by 

• Pulmonary congestion

• Pulmonary edema

• Pulmonary embolism

Stimulation of the J receptors results in 

• Apnea followed by rapid, shallow ventilation

• Hypotension

• Bradycardia

Pulmonary stretch receptors are responsible for Hering Breur Reflex.

Chemoreceptor stimulation causes increase in rate and depth of ventilation.

Receptors for tidal respiration are muscle spindles in the diaphragm and intercostal muscles.

questions.text: Maximum velocity of blood flow is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Aorta

Aorta has the least cross-sectional area. Therefore, the maximum velocity of flow is in the aorta.

choices.text: Hypoxia induced vasoconstriction of pulmonary capillaries
Increased pressure in the pulmonary capillary beds
Disruption of the endothelial barrier resulting in leakage of fluid and proteins into the alveoli
Hypoxia causing vasodilation of pulmonary capillaries resulting in increased fluid formation

questions.text:
A 65-year-old avid male hiker, resident of Manali (at 5000 ft) was hiking in Sikkim with two companions. They hiked to Nathula in Sikkim at 12,000 ft in one day. He suddenly complained of extreme tiredness, light headedness, dizziness, difficulty in breathing. He began coughing and complained of tightness in the chest. He was taken to the emergency of a local hospital. Examination revealed respiratory rate of 32 per min, heart rate of 125/min, bp 180/100 mm Hg, bluish discoloration of fingertips, crackles and wheeze on the right lower lobe. His X-ray chest was done and is shown:-


Which of the following is not a possible reason for the man’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hypoxia causing vasodilation of pulmonary capillaries resulting in increased fluid formation

The proposed mechanism for development of HAPE is uneven hypoxia-induced vasoconstriction resulting in increased pressures in capillary beds, subsequent fluid shifts, and vascular leakage. Disruption of the endothelial barrier results in fluid, proteins, and even hemorrhage into alveolar spaces.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with progressive shortening of breath. Which of the following corresponds with chronic blood loss?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Oxygen content = (oxygen in combination with Hb) + Dissolved oxygen
                             = [Hb (gm/dL) X 1.34 X % saturation] + [PO2 (mm Hg) X .003mL/dL/mm Hg]

Decrease in oxygen content of the blood is caused by:-

• Decrease in Hb (chronic blood loss, iron deficiency anemia, hemolytic anemia, etc.)

• Decrease in % saturation (CO poisoning, methemoglobinemia, sulphemoglobinemia)

• Decrease in PO2 (high altitude, hypoventilation due to any cause)

questions.text: What is the lung volume at the end of maximum expiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Residual volume

The lung volume at the end of maximum expiration is the residual volume. Residual volume is 1200 mL in males and 1100mL in females. 
Residual volume, FRC and TLC cannot be measured by routine spirometery.

questions.text: Which of the following tracts innervates the A gamma motor neurons?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Reticulospinal tract

Pontine reticulospinal tract increases the A gamma motor neuron discharge and medullary reticulospinal tract decreases the A gamma motor neuron discharge. All others supply the A alpha motor neurons.

questions.text: Which of the following GI secretions has the highest pH?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Brunner’s gland secretion

Saliva has a pH of 6.0 to 8.0 (usually 7.0 to 8.0).

Intestinal secretion or Succus entericus has a pH of 7.0 to 8.0.

Pancreatic secretions have a pH of up to 8.8.

Brunners’ gland secretion has a pH of up to 9.3.

questions.text: The receptors for the Hering- Breur reflex are located in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bronchi and bronchioles

The receptors for the Hering Breur reflex are located in the tracheobronchial tree. They respond to increased stretch to limit inspiration.

questions.text: Neurons located in which of the following release serotonin as their neurotransmitter?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Raphe magnus nucleus

Raphe magnus nucleus located in the pons secrete serotonin. 

Locus ceruleus- nor epinephrine

questions.text: The withdrawal reflex is initiated by stimulation of which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cutaneous free nerve endings

Pain stimulates the cutaneous free nerve endings which in turn is responsible for the flexor withdrawal response. 

Stimulation of muscle spindle causes the stretch reflex.

Stimulation of the golgi tendon organ causes the inverse stretch reflex.

Joint capsule receptors are responsible for position sense.

questions.text: Growth hormone secretion is most likely to be suppressed in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Acute hyperglycemia

Under acute conditions, hyperglycemia is most likely to suppress GH secretion. NREM  sleep, exercise, stress are stimuli that increase growth hormone secretion

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in hyperbaric oxygen therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased arterial PCO2

Hyperbaric oxygen works by increasing the DISSOLVED component of oxygen in the blood. The result will be 

• Increased arterial PO2

• Increased oxygen content in blood

• Increased tissue PO2

• No change in arterial pH or CO2

Indications for hyperbaric oxygen are:_

• Air embolism

• Decompression sickness

• CO poisoning

• Burns

• Crush injuries

• Compromised skin flaps

• Radiation necrosis

• Necrotizing infections

• Gas gangrene

• Intracranial abscess

questions.text: Which part of the body is represented superiorly and medially in the post central gyrus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

lower limb

Lower limb is represented in the superior and medial portion of the post central gyrus

questions.text: Which of the following water-soluble hormones does not need a second messenger?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Insulin

Insulin does not need a second messenger because the insulin receptor itself has tyrosine kinase activity. 

DAG is the second messenger for Growth hormone and cAMP for ADH and Glucagon

questions.text: Changes in which of the following does not affect respiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Arterial Na+ concentration

Changes in arterial Na+ concentration has no effect on respiration. Increase in arterial H+ and PCO2 will stimulate the chemoreceptors producing an increase in rate and depth of ventilation. Increase in arterial HCO3- concentration (alkalosis) tends to suppress the respiratory drive.

questions.text: PO2 of 8kPa corresponds with Hb saturation of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

90%

PO2 of 8kPa or 60mm Hg (1kPa = 7.5mm Hg) corresponds to a Hb saturation of 89%. 90% is, therefore, the best answer.

questions.text:
The following events occur in the carotid bodies on exposure to hypoxia are listed in random order: 

(1) release of dopamine

(2) excitation of afferent fibres of ninth nerve

(3) depolarization of glomus cells 

(4) decreased potassium conductance through O2 sensitive potassium channels on glomus cells

(5) opening of voltage gated calcium channels and calcium influx

What is the correct sequence in which the above occur on exposure to hypoxia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

4, 3, 5, 1, 2

On exposure to hypoxia, there is closure and decreased potassium conductance through O2 sensitive potassium channels on glomus cells. Accumulation of positive charge within the glomus cells depolarizes the cells. This leads to opening of voltage gated calcium channels and calcium influx. Increase in intracellular calcium causes release of dopamine by the glomus cells. Dopamine combines with its receptors (D2) on the ninth nerve terminal exciting the nerve terminals. Impulses go to the respiratory centre in the medulla resulting in an increase in rate and depth of ventilation.

questions.text: Migrating motor complex is triggered by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Motilin

MMCs, which occur in the inter digestive period, are triggered by Motilin secreted by M cells in the small intestine.

questions.text: Which of the following will cause the OHDC to shift to the left?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

CO poisoning

CO decreases 2,3-DPG causing a shift of the OHDC to the left. 

In high altitude, hypoxic hypoxia stimulates the peripheral chemoreceptors producing a hyperventilation. This results in a respiratory alkalosis, shifting the OHDC to the left. But in high altitude there is increased production of 2,3-DPG. The net result, therefore, is a slight increase in P50 and a shift of the curve to the right.
Anemia increases 2,3- DPG and shifts the OHDC to the right.

Exercise also causes increase in 2,3- DPG and shift of he curve to the right but this occurs only in untrained athletes.

choices.text: Decrease in bp from 120 mm Hg to 90 mm Hg

questions.text: Which of the following is likely to produce an increase in cerebral blood flow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Decrease in O2

The most potent stimulator for cerebral blood flow is increase in CO2 followed by decrease in O2 and increase in cerebral metabolic activity. 

Between a mean arterial pressure of 65- and 140-mm Hg, autoregulatory mechanisms maintain a constant cerebral blood flow. So, a change in bp from 120 to 90 mm Hg will not produce any change in blood flow.

choices.text: Control and co-ordinate movements of the axial muscles, as well as the shoulder and hip
Control and co-ordinate movements of the distal limb muscles
Function with the cerebral cortex to plan motor movements
Maintain balance and co-ordinate eye movements

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the functional role of the lateral hemispheres of the cerebellum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Function with the cerebral cortex to plan motor movements

The lateral cerebellar hemispheres (neocerebellum or cerebro-cerebellum) along with the motor cortex are involved in motor planning.

questions.text: Which anterior pituitary hormone plays a major role in the regulation of a nonendocrine target gland?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Prolactin

The major target tissue for prolactin is the breast where it stimulates the secretion of milk. The other anterior pituitary hormones (ACTH, TSH, FSH) stimulate other endocrine glands.

choices.text: The neonate experienced malnutrition in utero
The mother was malnourished during her pregnancy
The mother is diabetic, with poorly controlled hyperglycemia

questions.text: At birth, a large, well-nourished baby is found to have a plasma glucose of 17mg/dL and a plasma insulin concentration twice the normal value. What is the explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The mother is diabetic, with poorly controlled hyperglycemia

An infant born to a diabetic mother with poorly controlled hyperglycemia will have hyperglycemia and therefore, hyperinsulinemia in utero. The infant’s blood glucose may fall to less than 20mg/dL shortly after birth.

questions.text: Cortisone is administered to a 30-year-old woman for the treatment of an auto-immune disease. Which of the following is most likely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased insulin secretion

Steroids tend to increase blood glucose concentration. As a result insulin secretion is increased.

choices.text: Normal subjects after waking in the morning
Normal subjects who have taken dexamethasone

questions.text: When compared with late evening values typically observed in normal subjects, plasma levels of both ACTH and cortisol would be expected to be higher in which persons?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Normal subjects after waking in the morning

In healthy subjects, the secretory rates of ACTH and cortisol are low in late evening but high in early hours of morning. In patients with Cushing’s syndrome or in patients taking dexamethasone, plasma levels of ACTH are very low. Secretion of ACTH and cortisol would be normal in Conn’s syndrome.

choices.text: A normal secretory pattern of GnRH

questions.text: A man who has been exposed to high levels of gamma radiation is sterile due to destruction of the germinal epithelium of the seminiferous tubules, although he has normal levels of testosterone. Which of the following would be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

A normal secretory pattern of GnRH

Normal testosterone levels in this man suggest that the secretory patterns of GnRH and LH are normal and that his interstitial cells of Leydig are function normally.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has a mass in the sella turcica that compresses the portal vessels, disrupting pituitary access to hypothalamic secretions. The secretion rate of which of the following hormones would most likely increase in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Prolactin

Prolactin levels are normally inhibited by PIF from the hypothalamus. Obstruction of blood flow through the portal vessels would lead to reduced secretion of ACTH, GH, LH and TSH but increased secretion of Prolactin

questions.text: A heroin addict has chronically increased levels of TBG. This would result in which of the following in this individual?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

No change in metabolic rate

With chronically elevated levels of TBG, there is increase in total and bound T4 but free T4 is normal.

choices.text: Increased ADH secretion from the pituitary

questions.text: A 55-year-old man has developed the SIADH due to carcinoma of the lung. Which of the following physiological response will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased ADH secretion increases water reabsorption from the urine which increases urinary osmolality but decreases plasma osmolality. Low plasma osmolality suppresses both thirst and ADH secretion from the pituitary gland.

questions.text: Some cells secrete chemicals into the ECF that act on cells in the same tissue. Which of the following refers to this type of regulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Paracrine

Chemicals secreted into the ECF acting on the neighbouring cells is paracrine secretion

questions.text: Which of the following substances causes relaxation of the LES and fundus of the stomach during swallowing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Nitric oxideRelaxation of the LES and fundus of the stomach during swallowing is k/a receptive relaxation. It is mediated by afferent and efferent pathways in the vagus and the neurotransmitter involved is nitric oxide.

questions.text: The ileum and distal jejunum of a 25-year-old man are ruptured in a road traffic accident. The entire ileum and a portion of the distal jejunum are resected. What is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Vitamin B12 deficiency

Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the distal ileum. Resection of the distal ileum will result in Vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following substance added to the perfusate of an isolated rabbit’s heart causes the heart to stop in diastole?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Potassium- Severe hyperkalaemia causes  the heart to stop in diastole

questions.text: Sweat glands and piloerector muscles of hairy skin are innervated by which type of fibres?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cholinergic post ganglionic sympathetic

Sweat glands and piloerector muscles of hairy skin are innervated by cholinergic post ganglionic sympathetic.

questions.text: Cells of the adrenal medulla receive synaptic input from which of the following neurons?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Preganglionic sympathetic

Preganglionic sympathetic innervate the adrenal medulla. The axons of these neurons release Ach.

questions.text: In a muscle spindle, which of the following is responsible for the dynamic response?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Nuclear bag fibre

Dynamic nuclear bag fibre is responsible for the dynamic response. Static nuclear bag and nuclear chain fibres are responsible for the static response.

choices.text: Dorsal horn of the spinal cord
Ventral horn of the spinal cord

questions.text: Interneurons that utilize enkephalin to inhibit afferent pain signals are most likely to be found in which region of the central nervous system?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Dorsal horn of the spinal cord

Enkephalinergic neurons in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord inhibit afferent pain signals.

questions.text: An input neuron to a diverging circuit causes the membrane potential to change from -65mV to -55mV. Which of the following best describes this change in potential?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Excitatory post synaptic potential = +10mV

The potential in the post synaptic neuron becomes less negative- this is k/a EPSP. EPSPs are always positive. IPSPs are negative.

questions.text: Most of the energy for strenuous exercise that lasts for more than 5- 10 seconds but less than 1 to 2 minutes comes from which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anaerobic glycolysis

ATP stores and ATP from phosphocreatine can sustain exercise for another the first 5- 10 seconds only. Energy for strenuous exercise for more than 5- 10 seconds but less than 1-2 minutes is derived from anaerobic glycolysis. Release of energy by glycolysis occurs much more rapidly than oxidative release of energy, which is much too slow to supply the needs of the muscle in the first few minutes of exercise.

questions.text:
The following events occur at an excitatory synapse-

A. Ligand- gated channels open in the post synaptic membrane to allow influx of sodium

B. Synaptic vesicles bind to pre-synaptic membrane

C. Depolarization of pre-synaptic membrane

D. Opening of calcium channels cause influx of calcium 

Which of the following is the correct sequence?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

C, D, A, B

Arrival of the action potential at the pre-synaptic membrane, causes opening of calcium channels. This is followed by calcium influx. Vesicles in the pre-synaptic axon terminal bind to the presynaptic membrane. This is followed by exocytosis of the neurotransmitter. The neurotransmitter binds to its receptors on the post synaptic membrane leading to electrical changes in the post- synaptic neuron.

questions.text: If alveolar surface area is decreased by 50% and pulmonary fibrosis leads to doubling of diffusion distance, how will the diffusion of O2 be affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Decreases by 75%

Diffusion of gases across the respiratory membrane follows the Fick’s law of diffusion. 

Net transport 

= - (diffusion coefficient) (surface area) (concentration gradient)/ (thickness of membrane)

Transport is directly proportional to surface area and inverse to the thickness of membrane. If the surface area is decreased to half and thickness of membrane is doubled, transport is decreases to one-fourth or in other words, decreases by 75%.

choices.text: Can be blocked by specific transporters

questions.text: Simple diffusion and facilitated diffusion share which of the following characteristics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Simple diffusion and facilitated diffusion are examples of passive transport and therefore, do not require energy for transport.

questions.text: Most important buffer in the interstitial fluid is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bicarbonate

The principal buffer in the interstitial fluid is bicarbonate.

questions.text: Hypertonic 5% saline contains how much of Na+ in meq/l?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

854

1 equivalent of a substance = 1 mole of that substance/ (No. of metal ions) X (valence)

For NaCl, 1 equivalent = 1 mole 

5% NaCl = 5 gm of NaCl in 100mL = 50 gm of NaCl in 1000mL

58.5 gm of NaCl = 1 mole of NaCl

50 gm of NaCl = 50/58.5 mole = 0.854 mole = 854 millimole = 854 milliequivalent.

choices.text: ESV first decreases and then increases

questions.text: During exercise in physiological limits what is the effect on end systolic volume?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

During exercise increased sympathetic discharge increases force of contraction of the heart resulting in a better emptying of the ventricles and a decreased end systolic volume.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for Bezold Jarish Reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Capsaicin   

Ref: Ganong, 25thed/p. 592, 662

BEZOLD-JARISCH REFLEX

• Intracardiac injections of chemicals like serotonin, veratridine, capsaicin, phenyldiguanide activates this reflex

• Afferents for this reflex travel through unmyelinated vagal C fiber endings

• The reflex responses are:

 Apnea followed by rapid breathing

 Hypotension

 Bradycardia

• Clinical importance of Bezold-Jarisch reflex

 This reflex is responsible for sinus bradycardia seen during myocardial infarction

 This reflex is one of the cause for profound bradycardia and circulatory collapse after spinal anesthesia

choices.text: Gap junctions form a cytoplasmic “tunnel” for diffusion of small molecules (<1000 Da) between two neighbouring cells
Gap junctions are formed by proteins called connexons
Connexons in the membrane of one cell are lined up with connexons of a neighbouring cell to form dodecameric gap junctions

questions.text: All of the following are true about gap junctions except-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Gap junctions form chemical synapses

Gap junctions form electrical synapses. They for a low resistance path for bi-directional movement of ions, molecules, sugars and amino acids less than 1000 Daltons.

choices.text: Decreased renal blood flow, decreased glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure
Increased renal blood flow, increased glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure
Decreased renal blood flow, increased glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure
Increased renal blood flow, decreased glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: Which changes would you expect to find after administration of a vasodilator drug that caused a 50?crease in afferent arteriolar resistance and no change in arterial pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Increased renal blood flow, Increased glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure

A reduction in the renal afferent arteriolar resistance will increase the renal blood flow. More the flow into the glomerular capillaries, more will be the glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure.

questions.text: All of the following are present on the alpha subunit of the sodium potassium ATPase pump except-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Glycosylation site

Glycosylation site is on the beta subunit.

choices.text: Includes phagocytosis and pinocytosis, but not clathrin- mediated or caveolae dependent uptake of extracellular contents
Refers to merging of an intracellular vesicle with the plasma membrane to deliver vesicular contents to the ECF
Refers to the invagination of the cell membrane to uptake extracellular contents into the cell
Refers vesicular trafficking between golgi apparatus

questions.text: Which of the following is true about endocytosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Refers to the invagination of the cell membrane to uptake extracellular contents into the cell. It includes phagocytosis (“cell eating”) and pinocytosis (“cell drinking”), clathrin- mediated endocytosis and caveolae dependent uptake of extracellular contents.

questions.text: Sodium iodide symporter is present in all of the following except-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

NIS (secondary active co-transport) is present in

• Thyroid cells

• Salivary glands

• Stomach

• Intestinal epithelial cells (apical membrane)

• Gestational breast

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms for transport across the luminal cell membrane of an enterocyte is present in newborns and infants but not in adults?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Intestinal absorption of immunoglobulins (in colostrum) during early infancy occurs by endocytosis. This ability to absorb large molecules by endocytosis occurs during the first several months of life but is lost thereafter. Simple diffusion, facilitated diffusion, primary and secondary active transports are all normal processes in enterocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following ions is higher in the ICF?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

K+

questions.text: Which of the following aquaporin is involved in water reabsorption from the PCT?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aquaporin 1 is present on both the apical and basolateral membrane of the cells of the PCT. Water reabsorption in the PCT is solute driven and follows the osmotic gradient set up by the active transport of solutes, and isotonicity is maintained.

questions.text: If an artery is partially occluded by an embolus such that its radius becomes one- half the pre-occlusion value, which of the following parameters will decrease by a factor of 16?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Blood flow is directly proportional to the fourth power of radius. Decrease in radius to half reduces the flow to 1/16th of its pre occlusion value.

questions.text: The image below depicts which of the following types of cell-to-cell signaling?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Paracrine

The given image shows the paracrine cell-to-cell signaling mechanism. In paracrine signaling, the signaling molecules released by a cell only affect target cells in close proximity to it.

An example of paracrine signaling is the release of endothelin-1, a potent vasoconstrictor released by the endothelial cells.
Synaptic signaling is a special case of paracrine signaling (for chemical synapses) between neurons and target cells.

choices.text: At point E, the nerve is more excitable
Point C to D is due to opening of Na+ and closure of K+ channels
Point B to D is refractory period

questions.text: The sequence of events occurring during an action potential is shown below. Identify the true statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Point B to D is refractory period

The correct statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is point B to D is the refractory period.

questions.text: In an ideal solution, which of the following is correct? (P is osmotic pressure, n is number of particles, R is gas constant, T is absolute temperature, V is volume)-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

P = nRT/V. If T is constant, osmotic pressure is proportional to the number of particles in solution per unit volume of the solution.

questions.text: Which change would you expect in a patient consuming a high sodium diet (200mEq/day) compared with the same patient on a normal sodium diet (100mEq/day), assuming steady-state conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Decreased renin activity 

Sodium and, therefore, water retention increases the ECF volume decreasing renin secretion. Decreased renin will decrease aldosterone secretion. Reduction in aldosterone will reduce potassium secretion in the collecting tubules. 

Increase in ECF volume increases ANP and decreases ADH secretion.

questions.text: A clinical experiment is conducted in which one group is given 50gms of glucose i/v and another group is given 50gms of glucose orally. Which of the following can explain why the oral glucose load is cleared from the blood at a faster rate compared with the i/v glucose load?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

GLP- induced insulin release 

GLP-1 secreted by the L cells is k/a physiologic beta cell stimulating hormone of GI tract. It stimulates the release of Insulin by beta cells of pancreas. This effect will not be seen after i/v glucose.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents with complaints of increasing fatigue and weight gain. She also complains of dry skin. Her hair has also been thinning. Laboratory evaluation shows high serum TSH, low T3 and T4 levels. She is advised T3 supplementation. After administering T3 which of the following hormone level changes are most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Decrease in TSH 

The patient has primary hypothyroidism with low T3 and T4 and elevated TSH. Exogenous T3 supplementation rapidly suppresses TSH levels by negative feedback which in turn decreases T4 secretion from the thyroid gland. Furthermore, RT3 also decreases because less T4 is available for conversion.

questions.text: The double Bohr’s effect is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Placental circulation

The “double bohr’s effect” helps to increase fetal oxygenation. The transfer of carbon dioxide from the fetal to the maternal blood shifts the maternal OHDC to the right and fetal curve to the left, facilitating the transfer of oxygen across the placenta from mother to the fetus.

questions.text: The receptors responsible for rapid, shallow breathing are-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

J receptors

J or juxtacapillary receptors located at the alveolo capillary junction are stimulated by 

• Pulmonary congestion

• Pulmonary edema

• Pulmonary embolism

Stimulation of the J receptors results in 

• Apnea followed by rapid, shallow ventilation

• Hypotension

• Bradycardia

Pulmonary stretch receptors are responsible for Hering Breur Reflex.

Chemoreceptor stimulation causes increase in rate and depth of ventilation.

Receptors for tidal respiration are muscle spindles in the diaphragm and intercostal muscles.

questions.text: Maximum velocity of blood flow is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aorta

Aorta has the least cross-sectional area. Therefore, the maximum velocity of flow is in the aorta.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is k/a “hydrocholeretic”?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Secretin

Secretin increases the bicarbonate and therefore, water content of bile. Hence it is k/a hydrocholeretic.

questions.text: Assume you have a patient who need fluid therapy, and you decide to administer 2L of 0.45% NaCl solution intravenously. After osmotic equilibrium, which of the following will NOT be expected compared with before the infusion of the NaCl?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increase in intracellular osmolality 

Infusion of hypotonic fluid results in increase in TBW, increase in ICF and ECF volume but a decrease in ICF and ECF osmolality.

questions.text: A new seizure drug is being investigated that binds to and activates GABA-A receptors in the CNS. During their experiments, a researcher uses a micro electrode to measure the RMP of a neuron. He records RMP of -70mV. Which of the following membrane potentials is likely to be recorded following exposure to the drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

-75mV

GABA-A receptors are ionotropic receptors which cause opening of chloride channels, leading to hyperpolarization of the cell. GABA-A agonist will, therefore, cause the RMP of the cell to become more negative or -75mV.

questions.text: Given below are the changes in intravesical pressure as the bladder fills up with urine. When there is no urine in the bladder, the intravesical pressure is 0. By the time 30-50mL of urine has collected, the pressure rises to 5-10 cm of water. Additional urine- 200- 300mL- can collect with only a small additional increase in pressure. Beyond a volume of 300-400mL, collection of more urine causes a sharp rise in intravesical pressure. The reason(s) for the minimal rise in pressure during the filling phase is which of the following-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Both A and B. Urinary bladder is an elastic structure. Filling causes the bladder to distend. In addition, like other types of smooth muscle, the bladder muscle has the property of 
plasticity; when it is stretched, the tension initially produced is not maintained. The flatness of segment Ib (filling phase) is a manifestation of the law of Laplace. This law states that the pressure in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension divided by the radius (T = P X r/ 2w or P = T X 2w/ r). In case of the bladder, the wall tension increases as the bladder fills up but so does the radius. Therefore, the pressure increase is slight until the organ is relatively full. The normal function of the bladder is to store urine until it has reached capacity and until it is socially acceptable to evacuate urine. The bladder wall contains elastin, which allows it to stretch without a subsequent increase in pressure. Typical adult bladder capacity is approximately 350–450 ml.

questions.text: An 75-year-old man is waiting in the pre-op room where the air temperature is 21 degrees Celsius. He is wearing only a thin gown that is open at the back. Most of his body heat will be lost by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Radiation and conduction

questions.text: Which of the following proteins connects the lines marked as A and B (indicated by red arrows) in the following image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Titin

The above image is the electron microscope view of the muscle. Line A corresponds to the M line, and Line B corresponds to the Z line. The protein that connects the M line with the Z line is titin.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in hyperbaric oxygen therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased arterial PCO2

Hyperbaric oxygen works by increasing the DISSOLVED component of oxygen in the blood. The result will be 

• Increased arterial PO2

• Increased oxygen content in blood

• Increased tissue PO2

• No change in arterial pH or CO2

Indications for hyperbaric oxygen are:_

• Air embolism

• Decompression sickness

• CO poisoning

• Burns

• Crush injuries

• Compromised skin flaps

• Radiation necrosis

• Necrotizing infections

• Gas gangrene

• Intracranial abscess

questions.text: Which of the following will cause a decrease in plasma potassium levels by causing a shift in potassium from ECF to ICF?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Insulin excess

Insulin causes a shift of potassium from ECF to ICF causing a decrease in plasma potassium levels.

questions.text: Which of the following water-soluble hormones does not need a second messenger?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Insulin

Insulin does not need a second messenger because the insulin receptor itself has tyrosine kinase activity. 
DAG is the second messenger for Growth hormone and cAMP for ADH and Glucagon.

choices.text: Shift of OHDC to the right
Decrease in the number of mitochondria

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen during acclimatization to high altitude?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Decrease in the number of mitochondria

Acclimatization to high altitude is due to the operation of a number of compensatory mechanisms. These include:-Increased urinary excretion of bicarbonates. High altitude results in hypoxic hypoxia stimulating the peripheral chemoreceptors. The resulting hyperventilation results in respiratory alkalosis. Alkalosis suppresses the chemoreceptor response. Kidneys increase the urinary excretion of bicarbonates reducing the pH that increases the response to hypoxia. 
Shift of OHDC to the right- respiratory alkalosis at hugh altitude causes a shift of the OHDC to the left, but a concomitant increase in red blood cell 2,3- DPG shifts the OHDC to the right. The net effect is shift to right and a small increase in P50. Increased secretion of erythropoietin- hypoxia is potent stimulus for secretion of EPO from the kidneys. Hypoxia causes increase in the number of mitochondria, which are the site of oxidative reactions. Myoglobin also increases which facilitates the movement of O2 to the tissues, the tissue content of cytochrome enzymes also increases.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with chronic heart failure presents with a particular breathing pattern. His depth and rate of respiration are plotted as given below. The type of breathing abnormality seen here is-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cheyne-Stokes breathing

The type of breathing abnormality shown in the image is suggestive of Cheyne-Stokes breathing.

Cheyne-Stokes breathing is characterized by periods of waxing and waning hyperventilation separated by periods of apnea, as seen in the image. This pattern is seen at high altitudes and in patients with severe heart disease or brain injury.

questions.text: The most important factor which determines the movement of a permeant substance across the cell membrane is-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 
Diffusion coefficient of a substance is determined mainly by the lipid solubility of that substance

questions.text: The receptors for the Hering- Breur reflex are in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bronchi and bronchioles

The receptors for the Hering Breur reflex are located in the tracheobronchial tree. They respond to increased stretch to limit inspiration.

questions.text: The image below shows simple muscle twitch along with the time trace, recorded in a frog gastrocnemius muscle. Calculate the minimum tetanizing frequency. (The time tracer was made with a 100Hz tuning fork.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

25 per second

choices.text: Negative feedback system with error of zero
Negative feedback system with correction of zero
Negative feedback system with gain of zero
There is no such thing as infinite gain in a feedback system

questions.text: Which of the following describes infinite feedback gain principle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Negative feedback system with error of zero

For a negative feedback system,

Gain = correction/ error

If error is zero, the gain is infinite.

The control of arterial pressure by the renal- body fluid mechanism, where the arterial pressure always exactly comes back to equilibrium point, makes it an example of infinite feedback gain principle.

questions.text: Identify the marked region in the given spirometry-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Functional residual capacity

The marked area in the spirometry shows the total amount of air present in the lung after normal expiration. This is called functional residual capacity.

questions.text: Maximum CO2 transport in venous blood occurs as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

As bicarbonates

70% of the CO2 in venous blood is in the form of bicarbonates.

CO2 reacts with amine radicals of hemoglobin to form carbamino compounds.


The solubility of CO2 is 0.067mL/ 100 mL/ mm Hg. Venous PCO2 is 45 mm Hg. At this PCO2 the amount of dissolved CO2 in plasma is 2.7mL/100mL of blood. Arterial blood has a PCO2 is 40 mm Hg and the amount of dissolved CO2 is 2.4mL/100mL of blood. This gives a difference of only about 0.3mL/100mL of dissolved CO2 in venous and arterial blood. This is about 7% of all the CO2 normally transported.

choices.text: Decrease in bp from 120 mm Hg to 90 mm Hg

questions.text: Which of the following is likely to produce an increase in cerebral blood flow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Decrease in O2

The most potent stimulator for cerebral blood flow is increase in CO2 followed by decrease in O2 and increase in cerebral metabolic activity.

Between a mean arterial pressure of 65- and 140-mm Hg, autoregulatory mechanisms maintain a constant cerebral blood flow. So, a change in bp from 120 to 90 mm Hg will not produce any change in blood flow.

questions.text: Which structure serves as an “alternate pathway” for signals from the motor cortex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Red nucleus

Motor cortex sends fibres to the red nucleus in the midbrain which in turn gives rise to the rubrospinal tract. The rubrospinal tract is the “alternate motor pathway”.

questions.text: Identify the hormone from the picture-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Growth hormone

The image depicts the fluctuations of secretion of growth hormone throughout the day.

Growth hormone is found at relatively low levels during the day unless specific triggers such as strenuous exercise are present.

During sleep, on the other hand, large pulsatile bursts of growth hormone secretion occur.

questions.text: A heroin addict has chronically increased levels of TBG. This would result in which of the following in this individual?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

No change in metabolic rate

With chronically elevated levels of TBG, there is increase in total and bound T4 but free T4 is normal.

questions.text: Some cells secrete chemicals into the ECF that act on cells in the same tissue. Which of the following refers to this type of regulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Autocrine 

Chemicals secreted into the ECF acting on the same cells is autocrine secretion.

questions.text: A young woman is given daily injections of a substance beginning on the 16th day of her normal menstrual cycle and continuing for 3 weeks. As long as the injections continue, she does not menstruate. The injected substance could be which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

HCG

HCG has the same stimulatory effect as LH on the corpus luteum. Administration of HCG causes the corpus luteum to secrete estrogen and progesterone, preventing the degradation of the endometrium and the onset of menstruation.

choices.text: Right dorsal horn of spinal cord at the level of entry
Left dorsal horn of spinal cord at level of entry

questions.text: For a sensory nerve fibre that is connected to the Meissner’s corpuscles located on the fingertips of the right hand, the synapse with the second order neuron in the corresponding sensory pathway is in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Right dorsal column nucleus

Meissner’s corpuscle detects fine, well localized touch, slow vibration, texture and topognosis. Sensory fibres from the Meissner’s corpuscles travel in the posterior columns. Fibres of the dorsal column synapse with the second order neurons in the same side dorsal column nucleus in the medulla.
